qas.question: What had caused citizens to vacate their farms?
How could a candidate assure the vote of a poverty stricken plebeian?
What type of culture was a side effect of the rampant poverty of the average plebeian?
What caused the bankruptcy of many farmers during this era?
Who had bought the now bankrupt farms?

context: In the final decades of this era many plebeians grew poorer. The <a0_0>long military campaigns<a0_0/> had forced citizens to leave their farms to fight, while their farms fell into disrepair. The <a4_0>landed aristocracy<a4_0/> began buying bankrupted farms at discounted prices. As <a3_0>commodity prices fell<a3_0/>, many farmers could no longer operate their farms at a profit. The result was the ultimate bankruptcy of countless farmers. Masses of unemployed plebeians soon began to flood into Rome, and thus into the ranks of the legislative assemblies. Their poverty usually led them to vote for the candidate who <a1_0>offered them the most<a1_0/>. A new <a2_0>culture of dependency<a2_0/> was emerging, in which citizens would look to any populist leader for relief.
